title: Why are more tanks not like Sion?
body:
Sion is the embodiment of everything Riot fetishizes in a champion 

- telegraphed in a way that actually lets you avoid his attacks, so the punishment feels fair
- very high degree of player control; can sacrifice higher reward for reliability
- MUH COUNTERPLAYYYYYYYYYYY
- isn't one-dimensional and thus has a variety of builds and playstyles
- Feels pretty threatening for most of the game, even by himself

Why was this sentiment not echoed in the tank update or in the myriad of reworks that came around that point in time?

Galio

- Very reliable damage output, most of it's front-loaded
- Meant to be a niche counter-pick champion but his kit is valuable regardless of enemy comp (Amumu has similar problem but for his own team)
- Feels disproportionately punishing to the telegraphs he gives you, particularly on his CC chaining and his ult; can't cancel his taunt with crowd control

Probably the easiest to address because he's mostly just overtuned, but I wouldn't mind bigger changes that feel more anti-mage

Sejuani

- Telegraphed W tells you that she's going to hit more than she gives you the chance to dodge
- Very reliable crowd control, and on every single ability; damage has to be undertuned even for a tank to compensate
- Whether or not her niche power (melee stacking her stun) works for her is completely out of her control; doesn't feel fair for anybody involved
- Has no other purpose beyond her powerful CC
- Her main damage tool not being magic damage like everything else kills alternate builds
- Feels unbearable early-mid but after laning phase almost nobody should be worried about a solo Sejuani; still feels obnoxious when paired with her team

No idea how to salvage this; any changes that I would actually want would completely change the rework niche

Maokai

- Still has too-reliable normal abilities, have to be left undertuned and unsatisfying
- Too much focus is on his E, but there's not much counterplay to them because they can't be disabled or cleared, only outran. 
- Basically turned into a mage support and then got nerfed for it, hasn't been seen since
- Can feel extremely overbearing early on due to his bush control when wards/sweepers are at a minimum, but a non-issue later on because boots tier 2 + an MS item makes saplings worthless against attentive players 
- Ult is only good on ARAM; for how hard it is to get the most reward out of, it's very lacking in satisfaction

Maokai is salvageable but needs focus put into his not-E abilities. R should be made faster and more visible (like through fog of war), with maybe an ARAM-specific nerf as compensation.

Zac

- Hard CC on 3 out of 4 spells, yet still retains higher than average damage for a tank 
- Same as Galio, punishes you too hard compared to the telegraphs he gives; landing E all but guarantees his ult 
- Doesn't feel particularly high in counterplay even though that was a goal of the rework (his Q needed to change but spammable, instant AoE % damage is completely fine?)

probably just needs nerfs

Rammus

no idea how he actually is, to be frank. rammus players keep saying he's been neutered but I've seen him completely wreck shit more than a few times

More tanks should be like Sion.

I'll be honest, I've played sion a bunch too but it's mostly been with the max and spam e play style due to its reliability and early utility. People will also often build armour against you first despite the amount of mixed damage you do.

I've never found q max to be rewarding enough for how difficult the ability is to land, especially since you need to land an e beforehand in order to get a decent hit off.

I'd be ok if they decided to change sion's e to have a non scaling cooldown and a flat amount of slow to encourage more q max. That said he would need a pretty big buff to his q in order to justify a massive nerf like this. Something like the damage and slow on q would need to be changed. The slow amount and duration would need to scale with charge time, and the damage might need to start significantly higher at about half of a max charge and work it's way back up. (Remember Sion's q does 33% damage to minions so a max charge r1 q right now deals the same damage as a r1 e base damage.)

But for the most part, the q max is very defining to sion, and has significant windows of power. The only issue is how royally fucked he gets by champions with dashes, especially those whose dash puts them directly in top of or slightly behind sion where his q doesn't work. I think there should also be a small area of leeway around sion where units are knocked up anyway to prevent situations like these. 

I've been trying q max more lately and finding it's just as good as e max, although quite less reliable, and feel it should be somewhat more rewarding but in its current stance is fair and enjoyable.

I usually max Q or E depending on which is more reliable in my lane (unless it's jungle. Then it's always Q) first and then W second. 

People who max W last on Sion confuse me.

W last was good when the shield was shit and not worth the mana until lategame when you had the pool to support its stupid costs.

Now his shield is better than just a minion aggro nullifier and can be used in actual trades, therefore a max second is better. 

People still max q last most of the time because it's significantly too hard to land for how much it does, at least in laning phase, and also does reduced damage to minions. 

Notice that a fully charged rank 1 sion q does the same damage as the base damage (unamplified by pass through) of rank 1 sion e to minions.

Shen's CC qualifies him to be a tank in a weird way. He has one spell for CC, but can hit multiple people with it. Other than that his utility and ability to protect his carries from anywhere on the map make him an excellent tank.

{{champion:78}}, for example, has several ways to stop divers and protect her carries. Her W stops dashes, her E cancels them and she can lock people in place against terrain, and her ultimate can knock a whole dive group into the Milky Way.
And Shen can globally shield anyone, draw aggro from from his carries for a bit, and protect anyone around him (including himself) from a barrage of auto-attacks with a small dodge zone. Shoe fits.

Also, he focuses more on beating down one person than collectively disrupting the enemy team, which is strange for a tank. That's why people are confused why he's classified as a Warden and not a bruiser.
Imo tanks need high bases to jungle and interact in their lanes.

This is true, but with the rediculous amount of sustain now it's really hard to play a tank. Most meta top laners either make very good use of lifesteal, and/or have built in sustain. Fiora, kled, riven, renekton, Darius, jax, jarvan. These are the most picked top laners at the moment and all of them fall into this category. 

Only 6 of the top 20 meta top laners don't make great use of lifesteal, and don't have built in healing, but at least 2 of those run grasp and another two have the option to build sustain giving items that have some effectiveness.

Thus tanks (generally, there are ALWAYS exceptions to rules) get cucked in lane being unable to have any pressure.

I think there's not enough a tank can do to counter this excessive sustain at least in lane and that is why they (generally again) aren't good.
